Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 524126: Direct Property and Casualty Insurance Carriers
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division

Description: Zurich Capital Markets Inc. agreed to pay a $4 million penalty and $12.8 million in disgorgement to settle allegations relating to its role in providing financing to hedge fund clients that engaged in market timing of mutual funds and facilitating the hedge funds' deceptive trading tactics.

Zurich agreed to pay $25 million to resolve allegations that its former reinsurance group, which operated under the name Zurich Re and was later spun off in 2001 as Converium, designed three reinsurance transactions to make it appear that risk had been transferred to third-party entities when, in fact, the risk remained with Zurich-controlled entities.

Court: Superior Court of State of California, County of Orange

Private Litigation Case Title: David Wilson v. Farmers Group, Inc. Employees Profit Sharing Savings Plan Trust et al

Info Source: Farmers Insurance to Pay $4.3M, Associated Press, October 22, 2001 (via Nexis).
AG announces $2.4 million in refunds, Associated Press, July 25, 2003 (via Nexis).

Description: Metropolitan Property & Casualty, Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, Peerless Insurance company, Plymouth Rock Assurance Corporation and Pilgrim Insurance Company agreed to jointly pay a total of over $100,000 as part of a settlement of allegations they failed to provide updated at-fault accident determinations to a private data collection company after the state's Board of Appeals overturned the determinations. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among them.

Metropolitan Property & Casualty Co. agreed to pay over $1.3 million in settlement of allegations it mischaracterized Hurricane Katrina wind damage as flood damage to avoid having to pay out on insurance policies, which caused the state to pay extra financial assistance.

Metropolitan Property & Casualty Insurance Company, Plymouth Rock Assurance, Pilgrim Insurance Company and the United Services Automobile Association agreed to pay a total of $9 million in restitution, plus a total of $500,000 to the state, resolving allegations that they overcharged consumers for motorcycle insurance.

Company: Metropolitan Property and Casualty Insurance Co.
Description: Metropolitan Property and Casualty Insurance agreed to pay $50,000 to the Commonwealth and cooperate with an audit to determine restitution to policyholders who were made to pay surcharges that had been vacated by the Board of Appeal.

Company: Metropolitan Property and Casualty Insurance Co.
Description: Metropolitan Property and Casualty Insurance Co. agreed to pay close to $345,000 in restitution and $50,000 to the Commonwealth in settlement of allegations it refused to renew automobile insurance policies of policyholders that had not had an accident or traffic violation in the previous three years, which is prohibited under Commonwealth rules.

Company: Metropolitan Property and Casualty Insurance Co.
Description: Agreed to pay $1.8 million in restitution and a $40,000 donation to the Attorney General Aid Fund in settlement of allegations it did not provide the legally required discount for automobile insurance policyholders who had passive restraint systems (airbags and automatic seatbelts) in their cars.

Info Source: Universal Underwriters to Refund $2.4 Million to Auto Credit Insurance Policyholders, US States News, May 28, 2008 (via Nexis).

Description: Zurich American Insurance Company agreed to  pay $151.7 million in restitution, $20 million to the states and reform its business practices to settle multistate allegations that it unlawfully rigged bids for commercial insurance and made undisclosed payments to brokers for steering clients to Zurich.

The Ohio Attorney General and the Ohio Department of Insurance reached a settlement with Zurich American Insurance Company resolving allegations that the company conspired with other insurers and insurance broker Marsh & McLennan to eliminate competition, mislead customers and inflate premiums paid for commercial casualty insurance policies in Ohio, all violations of Ohio's antitrust and insurance laws.
Info Source: Ohio Enters Into $7 Million Settlement With Insurance Firm, US States News, October 25, 2006 (via Nexis).

Company: Zurich American Insurance Company et al.
Description: Zurich agreed to pay $37.5 million to settle claims relating to workers compensation surcharges.

Description: Universal Underwriter Insurance agreed to pay a $200,000 civil penalty plus restitution in settlement of allegations it failed to obtain knowing consent when selling credit insurance, failed to timely cancel policies on request, failed to fully disclose and screen for eligibility, failed to disclose exceptions to coverage, and used unlicensed agents while selling insurance in the state.

Description: Zurich American Insurance Company agreed to refund $4.56 million to policyholders of its New York statutory disability insurance policies because the insurer failed to spend at least 60 percent of total premiums on claims, as required under law.

Description: The largest Texas auto insurance carrier in the Farmers Insurance Group agreed to refunding approximately $11 million in premium overcharges to 800,000 Texas policyholders and reduce its current rates by 3 percent.
Info Source: FARMERS REFUNDS $11 MILLION IN TEXAS, BestWire, March 7, 2000 (via Nexis).

Description: Farmers Insurance Group agreed to pay $15 million to thousands of customers who paid too much in automobile surcharges after being in at-fault auto accidents.
Info Source: FARMERS INSURANCE TO PAY $15 MILLION FOR OVERCHARGES ON TEXAS AUTO POLICIES, BestWire, April 27, 2002 (via Nexis).

Description: $20,000 fine with $10,000 suspended with compliance plan for failing to use the correct company name on correspondence and email and by failing to consistently disclose all pertinent policy benefits and coverages to insureds when a claim was presented. RCW 48.05.190, RCW 48.30.010(1), WAC 284-30-670...
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: Company fined for accepting flood insurance applications from producers that did not complete the required National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP") training, paying commissions to non-compliant producers and accepting premium from those sales. RCW 48.17.153(1); RCW 48.17.153(2).
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: $50,000 fine for charging rates other than its filed and approved rates. The Company violated RCW 48.19.040(1); RCW 48.19.040(6), justifying the imposition of a fine under RCW 48.19.430.
